questions.text: Delusion of grandiosity is seen in all, except? (JIPMER MAY 19)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Compulsive neurosis (OCD)

  • OCD is a neurotic illness, unlikely to have delusion of grandiosity (psychotic symptom).
  • Frontal lobe tumour has disinhibition and can have delusion of grandiosity.
  • Schizophrenia mostly has delusion of persecution, but can have secondary delusion of grandiosity.
  • Amphetamine toxicity can have both delusion of grandiosity and as well as delusion of persecution

choices.text: Grade III : Patient is aware of his illness, but blames it on others or external factors
Grade II : Slight awareness of being sick and needing help but denying it at the same time
Grade IV : Emotional awareness of the motives and feelings within, of the underlying meaning of symptoms
Grade I : Complete denial of illness

questions.text: All of the following are correct with respect to different grades of insight, except? (AIIMS MAY 19)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

(Ref : Kaplan Synopsis 11th edn)

Insight: Degree of personal awareness and understanding of illness has 5 grades (Q)

  • Grade I : Complete denial of illness
  • Grade II : Slight awareness of being sick and needing help but denying it at the same time
  • Grade III : Awareness of being sick but blaming it on others, on external factors, on medical or unknown organic factors
  • Grade IV: Intellectual insight: Admission of illness and recognition that symptoms or failures in social adjustment are due to irrational feelings or disturbances, without applying that knowledge to future experiences
  • Grade V: True emotional insight: Emotional awareness of the motives and feelings within, of the underlying meaning of symptoms; does the awareness lead to changes in personality and future behavior; openness to new ideas and concepts about self and the important persons in his or her life.

questions.text:
SEQUENTIAL ARRANGEMENT (AIIMS NEW PATTERN)

Arrange the following stages of mania in order of appearance and severityâ€¦

1. Elation

2. Ecstasy

3. Euphoria

4. Exaltation
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

3, 1, 4, 2 (Ref : Niraj Ahuja)

The elevated mood can pass through following four stages, depending on the severity of manic episode:

a. Euphoria (mild elevation of mood): An increased sense of psychological well-being and happiness,

not in keeping with ongoing events. This is usually seen in hypomania (Stage I).

b. Elation (moderate elevation of mood): A feeling of confidence and enjoyment, along with an increased psychomotor activity. Elation is classically seen in mania (Stage II).

c. Exaltation (severe elevation of mood): Intense elation with delusions of grandeur; seen in severe

mania (Stage III).

d. Ecstasy (very severe elevation of mood): Intense sense of rapture or blissfulness; typically seen in

delirious or stuporous mania (Stage IV).

questions.text:
MATCH THE FOLLOWING (AIIMS NEW PATTERN)

Match the following diagnosis with minimum duration needed for treatment (as per DSM 5)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

A: 3 ; B : 1 ; C : 2 ; D : 5

questions.text: “Match box” sign is seen in? (PGI MAY 19)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Delusional Parasitosis

In this the person feels that body is infested with worms, so brings the worms to the doctor in a match box, which is empty. This is known as match box’s sign.

SIGNS IN PSYCHIATRY

  • Match box sign : delusional parasitosis
  • Otto veraguth fold : depression
  • Russel’s sign : Bulimia Stigmata
  • Grid iron abdomen : Factitious disorder

questions.text: Lobe atrophied in chronic schizophrenia? (JIPMER MAY 19)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Frontal lobe (Ref : kaplan)

“There is considerable evidence from post-mortem brain studies that supports anatomical abnormalities in the prefrontal cortex in schizophrenia. Functional deficits in the prefrontal brain imaging region have also been demonstrated. It has long been noted that several symptoms of schizophrenia mimic those found in persons with prefrontal lobotomies or frontal lobe syndromes”.

questions.text: Which of the following is schizophrenic first rank symptom? (JIPMER DEC 19)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Made affect

Schizophrenic first rank symptoms are: (Ref : Niraj Ahuja)

1. Audible thoughts: Voices speaking out thoughts aloud or ‘ thought echo’.

2. Voices heard arguing: Two or more hallucinatory voices discussing the subject in third person.

3. Voices commenting on one’s action.

4. Thought withdrawal: Thoughts cease and subject experiences them as removed by an external force.

 

5. Thought insertion: Experience of thoughts imposed by some external force on person’s passive mind.

6. Thought diffusion or broadcasting: Experience of thoughts escaping the confines of self and as being experienced by others around.

7. ‘ Made’ feelings or affect.

8. ‘Made’ impulses.

9. ‘Made’ volition or acts: In ‘made’ affect, impulses and volitions, the person experiences feelings, impulses or acts which are imposed by some external force. In ‘made’ volition, for example, one’s own acts are experienced as being under the control of some external force.

10. Somatic passivity: Bodily sensations, especially sensory symptoms, are experienced as imposed on body by some external force.

11. Delusional perception: Normal perception has a private and illogical meaning.

questions.text: Arnab is a model patient on the ward. He is never in any trouble. Whatever he is told to do he does. He sits quietly for hours, rarely talking, and hardly moving, except to ape the movements of those who pass by him. The most likely diagnosis for Arnab is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Copying the examiner, rarely talking (mutism) and hardly moving (akinesia) points towards diagnosis of catatonia.

Catatonic schizophrenia can be of two types: agitated and stuporous. Arnab is an example of the stuporous type. Residual phase means no or few apparent symptoms.

questions.text:
A schizophrenia patient on Haloperidol shows improvement in positive symptoms but develops akathisia and dystonia. Which drug can be beneficial the most in this patient?
(JIPMER DEC 19)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Lurasidone

These are extrapyramidal side effects due to haloperidol, lurasidone being only atypical antipsychotic in options, is a choice because it has lesser extra pyramidal side effects.

questions.text:
EXTENDED MATCHING TYPE QUESTION (AIIMS NEW PATTERN),

Match the given case scenarios with the most appropriate diagnosis from given options.

“THEME: Psychotic symptoms”

A 39-year-old woman comes to the physician accompanied by her husband. He says that for the past 3 months she has refused to eat any food that is not prepackaged. The patient also has placed a lock on the cabinet where she keeps her food and refuses to go to restaurants or eat at social events unless there is unopened, prepackaged food available. Otherwise, she is her normal self. She continues to work and recently received a promotion. The patient believes that someone is coming into her home and poisoning her food. A few months ago, she noticed a tiny hole in an apple at home and was convinced that someone had injected it with poison. She has no past psychiatric history. Except for these beliefs, her mental status examination is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Delusional disorder

This patient's 3-month history of delusions of being poisoned in the absence of other psychotic symptoms is consistent with delusional disorder. She does not exhibit hallucinations or disorganized thoughts or behavior. Her husband says that she is normal apart from her behavior around food, and she is functioning well at work. Delusions of being poisoned, harassed, or spied on would be classified as persecutory type, the most frequent subtype. Other subtypes based on delusional themes include erotomanic (false belief that someone of higher status is in love with them), grandiose (great talent, insights, or achievements), jealous (unfaithful partner), and somatic (bodily functions and sensations).

 

DSM-5 diagnosis of delusional disorder:

• 1 or more delusions for at least 1 month

• Other psychotic symptoms absent

• Behavior not obviously bizarre or odd; ability to function apart from delusion

• Behavior not due to substances or another medical condition

• Subtypes (erotomanic, grandiose, jealous, persecutory & somatic)

questions.text:
EXTENDED MATCHING TYPE QUESTION (AIIMS NEW PATTERN),

Match the given case scenarios with the most appropriate diagnosis from given options.

“THEME: Psychotic symptoms”

A 15-year -old boy is brought to the pediatrician due to his bizarre behavior. His mother has found him whispering to himself at night on multiple occasions over the past 2 months. When questioned, he told her that he was "talking with aliens from outer space" and insisted that the aliens were "transmitting thoughts from my brain to their planet." During this period, the boy has become more withdrawn and his school grades have steadily declined. He refuses to make eye contact and replies only in monosyllables. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (F)

 

Schizophreniform disorder

This patient's 2-month history of delusions, hallucinations, and negative symptoms is consistent with schizophreniform disorder. Schizophreniform disorder is diagnosed when the symptoms of schizophrenia are present for >1 month but <6 months. These symptoms include the presence of 2 or more of the following: delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech (frequent derailment or incoherence), grossly disorganized or catatonic behavior, or negative symptoms (affective flattening, asociality, and alogia). Impairment in functioning may be present but is not required for diagnosis. When the diagnosis is made without waiting for the patient to recover, it is specified as provisional. If symptoms persist beyond 6 months, the diagnosis is changed to schizophrenia.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man is brought to your emergency department under arrest by the local police. The patient was found naked at a busy intersection jumping up and down on top of a car. Interviewing the patient, you discover that he has not slept in 2 days because he does not feel tired. He reports hearing voices. The patient was previously hospitalized 1 year ago with auditory hallucinations, paranoia, and a normal mood. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Schizoaffective disorder.

This patient is suffering from schizoaffective disorder. Schizoaffective disorder is characterized by symptoms of schizophrenia plus mood changes such as mania or depression.

In this case, the patient is hearing voices, consistent with schizophrenia, and is experiencing a manic episode with the classic symptoms of public nudity and decreased need for sleep. Importantly, a diagnosis of schizoaffective disorder requires that the patient experience psychotic symptoms WITHOUT mood disorder for at least 2 weeks. The patient's history is consistent with this requirement.

choices.text: Suicide after taking low dose of drug
Suicide occurring at the time when the patient starts to recover

questions.text: Paradoxical suicide is seen in: (AIIMS MAY 19)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Suicide occurring at the time when the patient starts to recover

Patients with depressive disorders are at increased risk of suicide as they begin to improve and regain the energy needed to plan and carry out a suicide (paradoxical suicide).  (Ref : Kaplan)

questions.text: A 60-years-old man whose wife died 3 months back now starts to believe that his intestines have rotten away and that he is responsible for the death of his wife and should be sent to prison. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Psychotic depression

Psychotic depression. The symptoms in this question are suggestive of nihilistic delusions (intestine are rotting away) and pathological guilt (belief that patient is responsible for death). Both these symptoms are usually seen in patients with severe depression. The death of wife could have acted as the stressor that resulted in the development of severe depressive episode with psychotic symptoms (or psychotic depression).

questions.text: Which of the following features seen in a 12 y old child suffering from depression is not suggestive of   development of bipolar disorder later? (JIPMER MAY 19)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Psychomotor agitation (Ref : Kaplan)

questions.text: Mr. X was treated by a doctor for his sad mood and suicidal ideas and while doing so therapist is asking for his negative thoughts, worthlessness and tries to correct it. Which type of psychotherapy is she giving? (NIMHANS 19)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cognitive behavioural therapy (Ref : Niraj Ahuja)

Cognitive behaviour therapy (CBT) aims at correcting depressive negative cognitions (ideations) such as hopelessness, worthlessness, helplessness and pessimistic ideas, and replacing them by new cognitive and behavioural responses.

questions.text: Which of the following is correctly matched adequate antidepressant dose? (JIPMER DEC 19)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Amitryptiline 75-300 mg (Ref : Niraj Ahuja chart)

choices.text: Should definitely have an episode of severe depression
Minimum duration to diagnose is 2yrs
Should definitely have an episode of mania
Should have major periods of hypomania

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true about “cyclothymia”? (NIMHANS OCT 19)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Minimum duration to diagnose is 2yrs (Ref : Niraj Ahuja)

If symptoms consist of persistent instability of mood between mild depression and mild elation, the disorder is called as cyclothymia. These disorders are characterised by persistent mood symptoms which last for more than 2 years (1 year in children and adolescents) but are not severe enough to be labelled as even hypomanic or mild depressive episode.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the physician complaining that he is "just not feeling like myself." This feeling began soon after his younger brother passed away from cancer 3 months ago. The patient is no longer interested in work or going out with friends on weekends. He falls asleep relatively easily at night but awakes very early in the morning and is unable to fall back asleep. He admits to feeling "down in the dumps," especially when he first wakes up but says that his mood improves a little during the day. The patient often thinks about ways that he could have spent more time with his brother. He feels guilty about his brother's death being his fault "because I am worthless and could not love him enough." His poor energy and concentration have started to affect his performance at work, and he frequently thinks that he should just quit "because I am bringing everyone down." The patient has been eating less and has lost 3 kgs over the past few weeks.  What is this patient's most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Major depressive disorder

This patient meets diagnostic criteria for a major depressive episode (depressed mood, loss of interest, early-morning awakening, weight loss, low energy, impaired concentration, feelings of worthlessness, and excessive guilt lasting at least 2 weeks). He has no prior psychiatric history and so would be diagnosed with major depressive disorder. Although his symptoms developed in response to a stressor, they meet full criteria for a major depressive episode, thereby ruling out adjustment disorder and grief reaction.

The death of a loved one is similar to any other serious stressor that can trigger a major depressive episode.

(Choice A) Adjustment disorders are characterized by increased anxiety, depression, or disturbed behaviour that develops in response to a stressor. Symptoms must develop within 3 months of an identifiable stressor and last no more than 6 months after the stressor ends. In adjustment disorder with depressed mood, the full criteria for a major depressive episode are not met. By convention, if the patient's symptoms meet the full criteria for a major depressive episode, the diagnosis of an adjustment disorder is not applicable.

Not bereavement because symptoms are present for more than 2 months

(Choice D) Although this patient is grieving, his depression symptoms are more persistent and severe than those seen in a typical grief reaction. The dominant feelings in grief are loss and emptiness; in a major depressive episode, anhedonia and persistent depressed mood predominate. The sadness involved in grief will likely decrease in intensity over a period of weeks, with intermittent increases or "waves" following reminders of the deceased. In contrast, the sadness involved in a major depressive episode is more persistent and less specific. In grief, patients experience memories and thoughts of the deceased. A major depressive episode involves more negative and self-critical ruminations, with feelings of worthlessness and self -loathing.

choices.text: More common after life threatening trauma
Can be seen in seizure and migraine patients
More common in females then males

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding depersonalization? (AIIMS MAY 19)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Reality contact is lost

DSM-5 Diagnostic Criteria for Depersonalization Disorder

  1. Persistent or recurrent experiences of feeling detached from, and as if one is an outside observer of, one's mental processes or body (e.g., feeling like one is in a dream).
  2. During the depersonalization experience, reality testing remains intact.
  3. The depersonalization causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.
  4. The depersonalization experience does not occur exclusively during the course of another mental disorder, such as schizophrenia, panic disorder, acute stress disorder, or another dissociative disorder, and is not due to the direct physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication) or a general medical condition (e.g., temporal lobe epilepsy).

questions.text: For 3 weeks following an automobile accident where she watched her child die, a 28-year-old woman reports difficulty sleeping, headaches, and an inability to concentrate. Her family reports that she suffers from nightmares and violent emotional outbursts when awake. Since the accident, she refuses to either drive or ride in a car. The symptoms presented here are most consistent with a diagnosis of
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Avoidance of associated stimuli and nightmares after an identified traumatic event are the criteria for PTSD. But the timeframe, 3 weeks, makes acute stress disorder the better answer.

questions.text: Which of the following defense mechanisms is not involved in psychodynamics of OCD? (JIPMER DEC 19)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Suppression (Ref : Niraj Ahuja)

Sigmund Freud found obsessions and phobias to be psychogenetically related.

 

Isolation of Affect: By this defense mechanism, ego removes the affect (isolates the affect) from the

 

anxiety-causing idea. The idea is thus weakened, but remains still in the consciousness. The affect however becomes free and attaches itself to other neutral idea(s) by symbolic associations. Thus, these neutral ideas become anxiety-provoking and turn into obsessions. This happens only when isolation of affect is not fully successful (incomplete isolation of affect). When it is fully successful, both the idea and affect are repressed and there are no obsessions.

 

Undoing: This defense mechanism leads to compulsions, which prevent or undo the feared consequences of obsessions.

 

Reaction formation results in the formation of obsessive compulsive personality traits rather than

contributing to obsessive compulsive symptoms, while displacement leads to formation of phobic

symptoms.

 

Thus, the psychodynamic theory explains OCD by a defensive regression to anal-sadistic phase of

development with the use of isolation, undoing and displacement to produce obsessive-compulsive symptoms.

questions.text:
EXTENDED MATCHING TYPE QUESTION,

Match the given case scenarios with the most appropriate diagnosis from given options.

“THEME: Anxiety symptoms”

An 18-year-old female has just started college and is living by herself for the first time. For the past month, she has been increasingly anxious that someone is going to break into her house despite living in a quiet neighbourhood. She feels tense all of the time and is having difficulty sleeping through the night. As a result, she feels tired all day, which is beginning to affect her studies.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Adjustment disorder

Adjustment disorder requires the development of emotional or behavioral symptoms in response to an identifiable stressor within 3 months of the onset of the stressor. These symptoms cause impairment in the patient's life, but do not meet criteria for other psychiatric illnesses. This patient's anxiety stems from the fact that she is living alone for the first time, and her symptoms of tension and insomnia are starting to negatively affect her studies.

questions.text:
EXTENDED MATCHING TYPE QUESTION,

Match the given case scenarios with the most appropriate diagnosis from given options.

“THEME: Anxiety symptoms”

A 33-year -old woman reports worsening anxiety over the past eight months, beginning around the time she started a new job. She is having a difficult time concentrating because she keeps wondering if her children are safe at school. She also finds herself making mental lists of the things she has to do to prepare for a party she is having at her home next month. By the time she gets home, she feels exhausted and often snaps at her children and husband. During the night, she has a difficult time falling asleep and constantly worries about getting everything done at work. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

GAD

Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) is characterized by excessive worry over many aspects of one's life; including work, family, finances, health, etc. Patients with generalized anxiety disorder have a hard time keeping these worries out of their mind, which can cause significant impairment in their daily functioning. They also may frequently experience symptoms of fatigue, restlessness, difficulty concentrating, irritability, and sleep disturbance. The patient described in the above vignette displays many of the classic symptoms commonly seen in association with GAD.

 

(Choice A) Acute stress disorder is very similar to post-traumatic stress disorder, with anxiety symptoms developing after experiencing or witnessing an event that involved actual or threatened death or serious injury. However, symptoms in acute stress disorder do not last longer than one month.

(Choice D) Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is characterized by multiple obsessions or intrusive thoughts that cause significant anxiety, or forced engagement of repetitive compulsions in an attempt to avoid otherwise significant psychological stress. Patients with OCD often recognize the unreasonable nature of their thoughts and behaviors, but are unable to stop them due to ever-increasing anxiety.

(Choice E) Patients with obsessive-compulsive personality disorder have a preoccupation with orderliness and perfectionism that negatively impacts their functioning. They are often overly devoted to their work, are stubborn, and believe there is only one way to do things. They can have difficulty throwing out worn items, often have trouble with relationships because of their need for perfection, and even need to play games by following the rules precisely. They often do not see their behavior as a problem.

(Choice F) Patients with paranoid personality disorder have a life-long pattern of distrust and suspiciousness of others. They often read too much into things, accuse others of trying to harm them in some way, and bear grudges. However, their suspiciousness is not to the level of a delusion.

(Choice G) Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is characterized by symptoms of anxiety that develop after experiencing or witnessing an event that involved actual or threatened death or serious injury. Patients with PTSD often re-live the event through flashbacks or nightmares, avoid stimuli related to the trauma, may feel detached from others, and often have associated symptoms such as insomnia or hypervigilance. Symptoms of PTSD last longer than one month.

(Choice H) Patients with social phobia show a marked and persistent fear of social or performance situations accompanied by unreasonable fears that they will be humiliated or embarrassed. Affected patients will avoid these situations, and they can have panic attacks if forced into them. They usually realize that their fears are unreasonable and excessive.

questions.text:
A 41 -year-old woman agrees to talk with her physician at her husband's insistence. She says, "I've always had trouble throwing things away, especially magazines, newspapers, books, old clothes, and lots of miscellaneous household items." She thinks she may need the items again or wonders if discarded items may increase in value. Her husband is concerned that the large piles in their house continue to grow, making it difficult to move around or find a place to sit. The patient's family is embarrassed by her actions and refuses to have relatives or friends over to visit. She has attempted to clean rooms or throw things away on many occasions but always becomes anxious at the thought of parting with various items. She feels guilty and sometimes cries when considering the toll on her family. The patient has no problems with sleep, appetite,

concentration, or motivation. In addition to recommending cognitive behavioral therapy, what is the most appropriate initial treatment approach?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: An elderly patient, known to suffer from dementia, was found walking aimlessly in the fields in hot weather for several hours before being brought to the clinic. Which of the following would be the most useful laboratory test? (similar to PGI NOV 19)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

serum electrolyte levels

An elderly woman exposed to hot sunlight for hours may be dehydrated, and testing

serum electrolyte levels may confirm this suspicion for hyponatremia. Although the other tests (choices A, B, C, ) may be indicated at some point, they are not the most urgent tests in this case.

questions.text: Visual hallucinations are most predominantly seen in (AIIMS MAY 19)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Lewy body dementia

Features of LBD:

i. Fluctuating cognitive impairment over weeks or months, with involvement of memory and higher  cortical functions (such as language, visuo-spatial  ability, praxis and reasoning). Lucid intervals can  be present in between fluctuations.

ii. Recurrent and detailed visual hallucinations.

iii. Spontaneous extrapyramidal or parkinsonian symptoms such as rigidity and tremors.

iv. Neuroleptic sensitivity syndrome, characterised by a marked sensitivity to the effects of typical doses  of antipsychotic drugs (resulting in severe extrapyramidal side-effects with use of antipsychotics).

Other clinical features may include repeated falls,  autonomic dysfunction (e.g. orthostatic hypotension), urinary incontinence, delusions and depressive  features. Although Lewy bodies (intra-cytoplasmic  inclusion bodies) are also present in Parkinson’s  disease, the occurrence of Lewy bodies in Lewy body  dementia is more widespread. A PET (Positron Emission Tomography) or SPECT (Single Photon Emission  Computerised Tomography) scan of brain may show low dopamine transporter uptake in basal ganglia.

questions.text: A 38 year old male, known alcoholic, iv drug user, memory loss in last 6 months, motor incoordination, movement problems, confusion, brain shows cortical atrophy? (JIPMER DEC 19)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

HIV related dementia

Younger age of onset, presence of movement problems, rapidly progressive dementia, IV drug user, all these points towards diagnosis of HIV related dementia.

questions.text: In an alcoholic patient, which of the following causes “DELIRIUM TREMENS”? (AIIMS NOV 19)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Acute infection (Ref : Kaplan)

“Alcohol withdrawal delirium is a medical emergency that can result in significant morbidity and mortality.  Untreated, DTs has a mortality rate of 20 percent, usually as a result of an intercurrent medical illness such as pneumonia, renal disease, hepatic insufficiency, or heart failure. The essential feature of the syndrome is delirium occurring within 1 week after a person stops drinking or reduces the intake of alcohol. In addition to the symptoms of delirium, the features of alcohol intoxication delirium include autonomic hyperactivity such as tachycardia, diaphoresis, fever, anxiety, insomnia, and hypertension; perceptual distortions, most frequently visual or tactile hallucinations; and fluctuating levels of psychomotor activity, ranging from hyperexcitability to lethargy. About 5 percent of persons with alcohol-related disorders who are hospitalized have DTs. Because the syndrome usually develops on the third hospital day, a patient admitted for an unrelated condition may unexpectedly have an episode of delirium, the first sign of a previously undiagnosed alcohol-related disorder. Episodes of DTs usually begin in a patient’s 30s or 40s after 5 to 15 years of heavy drinking, typically of the binge type. Physical illness (e.g., hepatitis or pancreatitis) predisposes to the syndrome; a person in good physical health rarely has DTs during alcohol withdrawal.”

choices.text: Related gene on 6th chromosome MHC 2 HLA DR 2
Hyperactivity of orexin releasing neurons in hypothalamus
Inability of brain to regulate sleep wake cycle

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding narcolepsy? (JIPMER DEC 19)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

hyperactivity of orexin releasing neurons in hypothalamus

Narcolepsy has orexin/hypocretin deficiency

This is a disorder characterised by excessive daytime sleepiness, often disturbed night-time sleep and disturbances in the REM-sleep. The hallmark of this disorder is decreased REM latency, i.e. decreased latent period before the first REM period occurs. Normal REM latency is 90-100 minutes. In narcolepsy, REM-sleep usually occurs within 10 minutes of the onset of sleep. The common age of onset is 15-25 years, with usually a stable course throughout life. The prevalence rate of narcolepsy is about 4 per 10,000.

 

The classical tetrad of symptoms is:

i. Sleep attacks (most common): The person is unable to resist a sleep attack or ‘nap’, from which he or she awakens refreshed. These ‘attacks’ can occur during any time of the day, even whilst driving. Usually, there is a gap of 2-3 hours between the two attacks.

 

ii. Cataplexy: This is characterised by a loss of muscle tone in the various parts of body, e.g. jaw

 

iii. Hypnagogic hallucinations: These are vivid perceptions, usually dream-like, which occur at the onset of sleep and are associated with fearfulness. When these occur at awakening, they are called hypnopompic hallucinations.

 

iv. Sleep paralysis (least common): This occurs either at awakening in the morning (usually) or at sleep onset. The person is conscious but unable to move his body. The episode may last from 30 seconds to a few minutes and may cause significant distress.

 

Not all symptoms of the tetrad are present in one person. The other associated symptoms are fugue states, blackouts and blurring of vision. Polysomnography

helps in making a diagnosis in doubtful cases, showing a decreased REM latency.

The treatment consists of forced naps at regular times in the day, stimulant medication (such as

amphetamines) or modafinil in some patients, and/ or antidepressants (particularly when cataplexy is a prominent symptom).

choices.text: Schizotypal personality disorder

questions.text: A childhood friend makes a visit to your office. The last time you saw her was at her wedding one year ago. As the conversation proceeds, you ask her casually if married life is treating her well. She suddenly bursts into tears and admits that her husband is physically abusive, but that she can't leave him because she is deeply afraid of being alone. Going back to childhood, this woman has always had her parents make decisions for her, including those regarding her education and career. She has always been very pleasant and courteous in her dealings with others, and avoids arguments or disagreements whenever possible. Which of the following personality disorders does this woman most likely suffer from?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Dependent personality disorder

Explanation:

In this scenario, the friend's indecisiveness, inability to disagree with others, and willingness to stay in an abusive relationship for fear of being left alone are suggestive of dependent personality disorder. Individuals with this condition tend to be clingy and submissive, and crave the protection and care of others. They avoid taking the initiative because of feelings of inadequacy.

(Choice A) Schizoid personality disorder is characterized by an inability to express emotion and social detachment. These patients do not enjoy close relationships and prefer to be aloof and isolated. They rarely indulge in any pleasurable activities and appear indifferent to praise or criticism from others.

(Choice C) Schizotypal personality disorder is characterized by a pattern of odd and eccentric behavior and a reduced capacity for close relationships. These patients usually exhibit "magical thinking." They may have bizarre fantasies or believe in telepathy, clairvoyance, or the concept of a sixth sense. They often have paranoid ideation and unusual perceptual experiences.

(Choice D) Avoidant personality disorder is characterized by hypersensitivity to criticism, social inhibition, and feelings of inadequacy. Although these individuals want friendships, they avoid (as the name suggests) such intimate relationships because they fear ridicule. They also perceive themselves as inferior to others and are reluctant to engage in new activities or to take risks for fear of being embarrassed. Although they appear shy, individuals with this condition actually want to make friends.

choices.text: Observe the patient for 2 hours after giving meal
Increase the dose of anxiolytics
Increase the caloric intake from 1500 kcal to 2000 kcal per day

questions.text: A young girl with anorexia nervosa is on treatment. Even after taking adequate food according to the recommended diet plan for last 1 week, there is no gain of weight. What is the next step in management? (AIIMS NOV 19)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Observe the patient for 2 hours after giving meal (Ref : Kaplan)

“The following considerations apply to the general management of patients with anorexia nervosa during a hospitalized treatment program.

  • Patients should be weighed daily, early in the morning after emptying the bladder.
  • The daily fluid intake and urine output should be recorded.
  • If vomiting is occurring, hospital staff members must monitor serum electrolyte levels regularly and watch for the development of hypokalemia.
  • Because food is often regurgitated after meals, the staff may be able to control vomiting by making the bathroom inaccessible for at least 2 hours after meals or by having an attendant in the bathroom to prevent the opportunity for vomiting.
  • Constipation in these patients is relieved when they begin to eat normally.
  • Stool softeners may occasionally be given, but never laxatives.
  • If diarrhea occurs, it usually means that patients are surreptitiously taking laxatives.
  • Because of the rare complication of stomach dilation and the possibility of circulatory overload when patients immediately start eating an enormous number of calories, the hospital staff should give patients about 500 calories over the amount required to maintain their present weight (usually 1,500 to 2,000 calories a day).
  • It is wise to give these calories in six equal feedings throughout the day, so that patients need not eat a large amount of food at one sitting.”

questions.text:
SEQUENTIAL ARRANGEMENT (AIIMS NEW PATTERN)

Arrange the following symptoms of ADHD in order of their response to treatment (from earliest to last…

1. Acts before thinking, on the spur of the moment

2. Talks excessively

3. Doesn’t seem to listen

Correct Answer (B)

2, 1, 3 (Ref : Niraj Ahuja)

ADHD SYMPTOMS, response to treatment is in following order:

1. Hyperactivity

i. Fidgety.

ii. Difficulty in sitting still at one place for long.

iii. Moving about here and there.

iv. Talks excessively.

v. Interference in other people’s activities.

 

2. Impulsivity

i. Acts before thinking, on the spur of the moment.

ii. Difficulty in waiting for turn at work or

play

 

3. Attention deficit

i. Fails to finish the things started.

ii. Shifts from one uncompleted activity to another.

iii. Doesn’t seem to listen.

iv. Easily distracted by external stimuli.

v. Often loses things.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman notices a firm, fixed mass in her right breast but chooses not to seek medical care. The mass is then detected during her annual physical examination 8 months later. By that point, it has increased greatly in size, causing her discomfort. When asked why she did not report the mass when she first noticed it, she says, "I was waiting for my children to graduate from high school. I didn't want to have a bunch of doctors' appointments when I should be helping them with their homework."  This response is an example of which of the following defense mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Rationalization

Rationalization is an immature defense mechanism characterized by excusing an unacceptable behavior (or emotion) in a false but logically rational way to avoid the true reasons for the behavior. Immature defense mechanisms are typically maladaptive and prevent patients from coping with difficult issues in a productive manner. This patient was frightened about potential pain from cancer treatment and so used her children's

school work as a justification for avoiding the proper evaluations. This resulted in a delay in care and likely a more difficult treatment course.

(Choice A) Denial, an immature defense mechanism, is the failure to accept a disturbing aspect of external reality. An example would be if this patient refused to acknowledge that a potentially malignant mass is present despite obvious appearances or other evidence of cancer.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman comes to a psychiatrist for help with the management of her obsessive-compulsive disorder. She describes a repetitive thought that frightens her. This worry is to harm the family members by accidently lighting a matchstick in kitchen in presence of gas knob on. As a result, she finds herself checking the gas knob in her home at least 30 times a day. Which of the following defense mechanisms does this act of checking represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Undoing

Undoing is the defense mechanism which explains compulsive behaviours in an obsessive compulsive disorder. Undoing involves "magical" gestures or rituals that are meant to cancel out unpleasant thoughts or feelings after they've already occurred.

questions.text: After being struck on the head by an iron rod, a previously serious construction worker starts making inappropriate sexual remarks to his coworkers, is easily distracted, and loses his temper over minor provocations. What part of his brain has most likely been damaged?

Frontal Lobe

Patient is showing signs of disinhibition, probably having lesion involving frontal lobe.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman has thin legs and arms but a considerable amount of fat deposited on her abdomen, chest, and shoulders. Her skin is thin and atrophic and she has several purple striae on her abdomen. An MRI shows the presence of a pituitary adenoma. The psychiatric disorder most commonly associated with this syndrome is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Depression

Cushing’s syndrome, due to exogenous administration of corticosteroids and more rarely to adrenocarcinoma or ectopic production of ACTH, is often associated with psychiatric disturbances. Depression and mixed anxiety and depressive states are the most common psychiatric manifestations of the syndrome (from 35 to 68%, depending on the study). Mania, psychosis, delirium, and cognitive disturbances also occurs but at a much lower rate. Depressive symptoms occur early in the disorder—in 27% of cases in the prodromal period. Most patients improve after the primary disorder is treated and serum cortisol decreases.

choices.text: A history of severe extrapyramidal symptoms while on haloperidol
The presence of mild tardive dyskinesia
A history of recurrent depressive symptoms

questions.text: A patient with schizophrenia has had a poor response to several trials of typical antipsychotic medications, risperidone and olanzapine. His psychiatrist recommends a trial of clozapine. What factor can represent a relative contraindication to the use of this medication?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

A seizure disorder

Clozapine has been proved to be effective in reducing psychotic symptoms in refractory cases of schizophrenia and schizoaffective disorder. Its use is limited by two serious side effects: agranulocytosis (1 to 2%) and an increased risk for seizures. An antiepileptic medication can be added when the use of clozapine is justified by the potential benefits of this medication. Clozapine does not cause galactorrhea or Parkinsonism and can benefit patients with tardive dyskinesia

choices.text: Schizophrenic patients do not need constant encouragement to stay motivated
Family style of interaction makes no difference in the prognosis
Intrusive and critical families have a detrimental effect on schizophrenic patients
Family therapy has not proved to be of value in the treatment of schizophrenia

questions.text: A young man with a diagnosis of paranoid schizophrenia is hospitalized for the third time in the space of six months for acute exacerbations of his symptoms. He has been compliant with his antipsychotic medications and has kept his monthly doctor appointments. When his parents come to visit, they worry about the patient’s unkempt appearance and urge him to take better care of yourself. They show their disappointment when they learn that the patient has not participated in groups and has been spending most of his time in his room. Choose the most appropriate statement:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Intrusive and critical families have a detrimental effect on schizophrenic patients

Combined with antipsychotic medication, family therapy has been proved to reduce the relapse rate in schizophrenia. Most effective interventions include educating family members about the nature of schizophrenia and the needs of schizophrenic patients.  Family therapy can improve the patient’s quality of life by bringing about a decrease in the level of criticism, a decrease in the family members’ emotional overinvolvement with the patient, and a lowering of the overall emotional tone of family interactions. Pathological family interactions have a negative effect on the prognosis but are not the primary cause of schizophrenia.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is diagnosed with a psychotic depression and is started on imipramine and perphenazine. When he develops a dystonia, he is begun on benztropine 2 mg/day. One week later, his wife reports that the patient has become unusually forgetful and seems disoriented at night. On physical examination, the man appears slightly flushed, his skin and palms are dry, and he is tachycardic. He is oriented to name and place only. He showed none of these symptoms during his last appointment. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The described symptoms appeared after introduction of Benztropine (a centrally acting anticholinergic). It is known to cause confusion, disorientation and known as anticholinergic syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about neuroleptic induced dystonia:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Acute dystonia may cause impaired swallowing or breathing ; laryngeal - pharyngeal spasm may necessitate urgent intervention. It may also cause oculogyric crises, with the eyes deviated, spasms of the jaw causing trismus or grimacing, difficulties with speech, or abnormal positioning of the head (torticollis), trunk, or limbs Onset is usually within 24 to 48 hours of starting a neuroleptic or after increases in dosage of such agents. treatment of acute dystonic reactions includes immediate intramuscular (Intravenous if laryngeal spasm) infections of antiparkinsonian agents such benztropine or diphenhydramine HCL. Risk factors include being young, male use of high- potency neuroleptics and high doses and parenteral administration of neuroleptics.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect concerning pharmacotherapy in pregnancy:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The neonate may experience withdrawal symptoms from tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs), which can include tachycardia. tachycardia, tachycardia, irritability, hypertonia, and cyanosis. Review of several studies of TCAs have reported malformation rates with in the normal baseline rate of 2% to 4%. Lithium may cause cardiovascular malformations if used in the first trimester in approximately 1 in 2000, which is less than previously reported. It is also associated with neonatal toxicity and goiter formation (can be assessed by ultrasound). Information about SSRIs is accumulating, and so far, no increased rate of malformation has been reported. However, higher rates of spontaneous abortion versus controls have been reported for women versus control have been reported for women treated with both TCA and SSRI. The risk of neural tube defects (NTD) in those exposed to carbamazepine is 1% those exposed to valproic acid have a 1% to 2% risk of NTD, as well as increased risk of intrauterine growth retardation.

questions.text: Which of the following is false concerning the management of NMS:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Anticholinergic agents should be tapered slowly as they may interfere with thermoregulation Management includes supportive treatment in an intensive care environment with careful monitoring of vital signs. and respiratory and renal function. pyrexia electrolyte abnormalities and blood pressure abnormalities should be treated symptomatically. antipsychotic medication must be stopped agitation may be treated with benzodiazepines which may be an effective treatment in itself. Treatment includes dantrolene a direct acting muscle relaxant intravenously initially and then orally when the patient can swallow. it should not be used in conjunctions with calcium channel blockers. Side effects include impaired respiratory or hepatic function and should be monitored. Bromocriptine or amantadine may also be used orally.

questions.text: Autism may be associated with other neurologicdisorders except:

Wilsonâ€™s  disease   is   an   autosomal  recessive   disorder   in  which  copper   accumulates  because   of   a  mutation  in the  copper transport  gene  causing    liver,  basal  ganglia  ,  and   other   organ  damage  .  it   is   characterized   by  a   large   amplitude  tremor,  parkinsonian   symptoms,    and  nonspecific   psychiatric    symptoms  ,   but   not   autism   .  It   usually  presents  in the  teenage    years. Autism can be  associated    with various   neurologic   diseases, including  tuberous   sclerosis   and  fragile    syndrome.    Autism   may  also  be   associated  with  maternal   rubella.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect concerning the symptoms of PMDD?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

These  symptoms  are  now   thought  to  be   initiated  by  the  mid-  cycle  peaks   of  progesterone  and  estradiol   as  opposed  to  late-luteal   phase  decreases.  The   criteria   for  this   disorder   includes  more than  five  of the  following symptoms:  depressed  mood, anxiety  or  tension  labile   affect    anger   or  irritability ,  decreased   interest  in  usual activities ,  impaired   concentration,   decreased   energy,  a  change  in  appetite   (  either   increased   or  decreased ),  and  insomnia  or  hypersomnia,   These  symptoms   should  appear  only   after   ovulation   ,  should  have  diminished   by  days  4  to   5  of   the menstrual  period,  and  be documented  to  occur  in  two  or  more  consecutive  cycles.  Average  age   of  onset  is  reported  to  be   in the   middle  to  late  20s,  and  sufferers  have a  strong  family  history  of  major  depression.  Remission  has  been  reported   during  nonvulatory  cycles, which may  be  spontaneous,  suppressed  ,  or  due  to  menopause.

questions.text: Abnormalities in which of the following systems have not been reported in catatonia:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The  dopaminergic  system   may  be  hyperactive  and  paradoxical   reaction   to  lorazepam  with  excitement, not  sedation     implicate   abnormalities   of the  GABAergic  system   particularly  the GABAa  receptors   . Glutamate  is  implicated  by  the   response  of   some  patients   to  amantadine  , an  NMDA    antagonist. There  is no   evidence  that  the   cholinergic   system  plays   a  role  in the  development   of  this   condition .  The  role  of serotonin  still  needs   clarification   but  it  may   be  associated   with  disequilibria   of its   receptor  system.

questions.text: All of the following may directly cause or mimic depression except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Depression  can  be  caused   or  mimicked  by  medical  illnesses,   and   can   be   associated  with    certain  medications.  Depression  can  be   associated   with   strokes    ( especially  left  hemisphere  Near  frontal   pole) or  dementia,  and   is  very  common   in   Parkinson   disease (40%)  .  disease   like   hypothyroidism  and  certain  cancer (e.g.,  pancreatic   )   can   also   cause  or  present  as  depression  .  anemia  or  CHF can   mimic    depression  because  of  overlapping   Meds like sedative/hypnotics,  prednisone,  and  beta  blockers   can  be  associated  with  depression  dementia   
And  beta  blockers  can  be   associated   with  depression. Dementia  may  mimic  depression ; for  example for  example,  in   Alzheimer  disease  patients   complain   of  de  creased  interests ,  apathy   poor   concentration   and  decreased   energy.  Although patient with  laryngeal  cancer   may  become  depressed,   it  does  not  directly  cause  or  mimic  depression.

questions.text: Which of the following features predicts a good response to lithium treatment in bipolar patients with acute mania?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Milder forms of mania respond better to lithium than severe mania. Patients with classical features of mania respond better than those with schizoaffective presentation. On a similar note, dysphoric mania, mixed affective episodes, and rapid-cycling mania respond poorly to lithium
treatment. Having a family history of bipolar illness is suggestive of good prophylactic response of
lithium in relapse prevention; such an effect is not clearly demonstrated for the effects of lithium
in treating acute mania.

questions.text: Patients with undiagnosed subsyndromal hypomania have clinical characteristics closely resembling which one of the following diagnoses?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

In large epidemiological studies, a consistent 1.5% prevalence is quoted for bipolar
disorders. It is unclear whether there is an over-inclusion of depressive disorders and underdiagnosis of bipolar type 2 disorder in these surveys. Hypomania, being positively appraised
by patients themselves, is often missed in structured, non-clinician interviews. Angst et al., in a
20-year-long prospective study, observed that patients with depression and clinically undiagnosed
subsyndromal hypomania have similar risk factors, course, and outcome compared to bipolar
disorder type 2.

questions.text: A 45-year-old depressed man becomes clingy and tearful when his wife visits him. He adapts a fetal posture and sleeps on her lap. Which of the following is being exhibited?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Regression refers to moving back on oneâ€™s developmental behaviours at times of crisis, as exemplified in the question. Repression is the shifting of conscious conflicts to the unconscious,
leading to reduced anxiety. Sadism is purposeful inflicting of pain on oneself.

questions.text: Which personality is included as schizophrenia precursor?

questions.text: Alpha waves in EEG are best recorded over which EEG leads?

questions.text:
A 72-year-old lady complains of being infested with body lice. Her dermatologist could not find any signs of infestation but she insists that she could feel the lice moving on her skin and brings a matchbox full of skin scrapings for examination. Which of the following descriptions is most
appropriate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Delusional infestation (Ekbomâ€™s syndrome) is a delusion of parasitic (macroscopic) infestation with classical matchbox sign. An old lady comes to clinic with a match box of skin scrapings, as evidence for the parasite that infests her, causing itching. This can predate the onset of dementia. It may or may not be associated with a somatic tactile hallucination. It is not the same as compulsive skin picking, where the psychopathology is one of compulsion and not delusion. In factitious dermatitis, patients seek medical attention without obvious monetary gain in order to be in a patient role. They induce skin lesions using chemicals or medicinal products in order to â€˜become a patientâ€™.

questions.text:
A patient who has taken lithium for some months discontinues it and says
â€˜the ocean needs a sail as rat needs a tail, so write your exam and donâ€™t fail, results will be out in a mailâ€™. Which of the following symptoms is he exhibiting?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Clang associations

Sail-tail-fail-mail (rhyming is observed which is characteristic of clang associations)

Not flight of ideas, because no specific one word connection

Not tangentiality, because no evidence of losing the track

Not Neologisms, because no new words used

Treatment of ADHD:

  • Stimulants : Methylphenidate(DOC), Amphetamines
  • Non- Stimulants : Atomoxetine, Bupropion, Clonidine, Guanfacine

Atomoxetine is the first nonstimulant drug to be approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) as a treatment of ADHD in children, adolescents, and adults.  Atomoxetine is believed to produce a therapeutic effect through selective inhibition of the presynaptic norepinephrine transporter (Ref : Kaplan).

choices.text: Depression on top of neurotic depression
Depression on top of psychotic depression

questions.text: The term â€œdouble depressionâ€ is used for :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Double depression is depression on top of neurotic depression (dysthymia)

questions.text: Feature of narcolepsy includes all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Narcolepsy involves REM sleep disturbance. Sleep attacks, cataplexy, Hypnagogic and Hypnopompic hallucinations are characteristic

questions.text: Treatment of choice for bulimia nervosa include:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

For Bulimia nervosa, we use a combination of drug (SSRI) and psychotherapy (BT)

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman is being evaluated in the sleep laboratory. She is noted to have a decreased latency of REM. Which of the following disorders is this woman most likely to be suffering from?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

A decreased latency of REM sleep is seen in major depression. Depression is the psychiatric disorder that has been most associated with disruptions in biological rhythms. Besides the decreased latency of REM sleep, early morning awakening and other neuroendocrine perturbations are often found with major depression
